title: fastlite_dataclass_default_functional
text: This file will become your README and also the index of your documentation.

title: fastlite_dataclass_default_functional
text:
Developer Guide
If you are new to using nbdev here are some useful pointers to get you started.

Install fastlite_dataclass_default_functional in Development mode
# make sure fastlite_dataclass_default_functional package is installed in development mode
$ pip install -e .

# make changes under nbs/ directory
# ...

# compile to have changes apply to fastlite_dataclass_default_functional
$ nbdev_prepare

title: fastlite_dataclass_default_functional
text:
Usage

Installation
Install latest from the GitHub repository:
$ pip install git+https://github.com/ozpau/fastlite_dataclass_default_functional.git
or from conda
$ conda install -c ozpau fastlite_dataclass_default_functional
or from pypi
$ pip install fastlite_dataclass_default_functional


Documentation
Documentation can be found hosted on this GitHub repository’s pages. Additionally you can find package manager specific guidelines on conda and pypi respectively.

title: fastlite_dataclass_default_functional
text:
How to use
Fill me in please! Don’t forget code examples:

1+1

2

title: core
text:
from fastlite import *


db = database(':memory:')


db.q("""
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS migrations (
    id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, inserted_at DATETIME DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP NOT NULL
);
""")

[]



def list_records(): return db.q("SELECT * FROM migrations")
list_records()

[]



migrations = db.t.migrations
Migration = migrations.dataclass()

Creating Migration with dataclass copies default value that is an SQL function:

m = Migration(name='setup_db')
m

Migrations(id=UNSET, name='setup_db', inserted_at='CURRENT_TIMESTAMP')



migrations.insert(m)

Migrations(id=1, name='setup_db', inserted_at='CURRENT_TIMESTAMP')


Inserting this record doesn’t execure the SQL function as expected:

list_records()

[{'id': 1, 'name': 'setup_db', 'inserted_at': 'CURRENT_TIMESTAMP'}]


Now let’s do a similar insert using raw SQL:db.q(“SELECT * FROM migrations”)

db.q("INSERT INTO migrations (name) VALUES('create_users')")

[]



list_records()

[{'id': 1, 'name': 'setup_db', 'inserted_at': 'CURRENT_TIMESTAMP'},
 {'id': 2, 'name': 'create_users', 'inserted_at': '2025-03-08 15:23:30'}]


As you can see, the SQL function got called as it should.
